bibl.title: Letter fragment from Walter Reed to [Emilie B. Lawrence], [1875?]

div1.p: Reed inquires if [Emilie Lawrence] is attached, and asks if he may visit her.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Walter Reed to [Emilie B. Lawrence], [1875?]
div1.p:
I have only considered you
to be a pure, amiable, & sen-
sible lady, worthy & more
than worthy of all of the love
that so imperfect a man
as I can bestow.

But there is no use for me to
write at length on this matter-
It has been truly said that
“seeing is believing” & since this
is so, I am anxious to meet
you face to face once more.
Of course, all depends upon
your permission -- I do not ask
whether my visit will repay
me-- I simply desire to know
whether it would be agree-
able to you to have me spend
a few days in Murfreesboro.
If so, I would only be too happy
to appear “in propia persona”.

Before closing
my letter, I desire to ask one
question which you will please
do me the kindness to answer.
Are your affections engaged,
or are they free & unfettered?
This I am aware should have
been asked long ago, but I must
plead my want of acquaintance
with such matters as my
sole excuse.

I pray that you have
will not take umbrage at
anything I have written in
this letter -- That I have spoken
plainly I know. But, Miss E.,
I am so thoroughly in ear-
nest in all that I have pro-
fessed, that to doubt me is
to grieve me.

May I request that
you will favor me with an
early reply,
div1.closer:
I remain,
As ever, very truly,
Your friend, Walter Reed.
P.S.
I have received information
that I will not be assigned
to duty till June 1st, & prob-
ably later, so that I will
have abundant time to visit
your town, if you approve
of my coming--
W.R.
